_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: State of Alaska CAA Title V Operating Permit

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Central Gas Facility (CGF) is classified as NAICS code 211111, Crude Petroleum and Natural Gas Production.  Prior applicability analysis performed by an earlier operator of CGF demonstrated that the facility was not covered by RMP, due to the A¿naturally occurring hydrocarbonA¿ exemption. While BP Exploration Alaska Inc. (BPXA) concurs with that analysis, a Program 1 plan for the propane refrigeration process is being submitted.


Description of  stationary source and regulated substances handled

CGF is designed to improve overall field gas off-take by recovering NGL and miscible injectant (MI) from the gas and then (together with the Central Compressor Plant [CCP]) compress and return the remaining residue gas into the gas cap of the Prudhoe Bay reservoir.  The NGL and MI products are captured from the feed gas stream using a refrigeration/condensation process.  Current production is approximately 60,000 barrels per day of natural gas liquids (NGL) with a portion of that production shipped to Kuparuk oil field for MI injection.  The remaining NGL production is blended with crude oil and sent to Pump Station 1 (operated by Alyeska Pipeline Service Company).  Approximately 350 million standard cubic feet per day (MMscfd) of MI product is produced for use in the Prudhoe Bay oil field.  When compressed and re-injected into the oil bearing formation, MI lowers the viscosity of the crude oil, allowing it to flow to the well bore more easily.  The overall effect is a significant increase in recoverable oil.  

CGF utilizes propane in a refrigeration system.  The propane refrigeration system is a closed circulating loop.  Liquid propane is generally manufactured at CGF, stored in the 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum and added as make-up to the 19-1216 surge drum as needed.  The propane refrigerant system includes the following equipment and approximate inventories:

A¿	The 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum provides liquid propane storage for make-up.  At norma

l operating level, the storage drum contains approximately 90,000 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 379,627 lbs.
Catastrophic loss of inventory of the refrigerant storage drum is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations.
A¿	The 19-1216 refrigerant surge drum provides liquid propane storage.  At normal operating level, the surge drum contains approximately 40,000 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 168,723 lbs.
A¿	An economizer system facilitates compression of propane refrigerant in multiple stages, which improves overall system efficiency: 
o	At normal operating level, the LP economizer contains approximately 12,945 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 54,603 lbs.
o	At normal operating level, the HP economizer contains approximately 16,052 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 67,709 lbs.
A¿	Four chillers (19-1310, 19-1360, 19-1386A and 19-1386-B) allow for heat exchange between incoming process natural gas and propane refrigerant.  At normal operating levels, a chiller contains approximately 9,333 gallons @ 4.2 lbs/gal = 39,367 lbs.

Total propane inventory onsite is approximately 710,000 lbs.

The refrigerant storage drum is located along the West edge of the CGF facility pad, slightly North of center.  This orientation provides for better potential dispersion from bimodal Southwest/Northeast winds.

Catastrophic loss of inventory of the 19-1218 refrigerant storage drum and subsequent vapor cloud explosion (VCE) is the basis for the Worst Case Scenario calculations.  The model used was a TNT Equivalent Calculation.

Other Information Required Per 40 CFR 68.155:

CGFA¿s accidental release prevention and emergency response policies are predicated on compliance with OSHAA¿s Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps include process hazard analysis (PHA) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA).  The facility has had no accidents in the past five years from covered processes that resulted in deaths, inj

uries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  The emergency response program was developed consistent with OSHAA¿s Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response (HAZWOPER) and PSM standards, as well as other applicable regulations.  Planned changes to improve safety occur through the OSHA VPP process. 

Enclosed modules which house process equipment operated at CGF are equipped with fire suppression systems.  In the event of fire, HalonA¿1 fire suppressant is automatically released to inhibit the chemical reaction of combustion and extinguish the flames.  

Prudhoe Bay has its own professionally-trained fire department which responds and serves as the local fire department.  There is no other jurisdiction providing emergency response at CGF, with the exception of mutual aid provided by the fire departments of other nearby North-Slope Alaska oil fields.

The CCP & CGF Onshore Site Manager (OSM) is a position having two A¿alternatesA¿, which work a 12 hour shift on a scheduled rotation (e.g.- 1 week on, 1 week off, etc).  The two alternates share common contact information (phone and e-mail).   RMP*ESubmit instructions limit entry in Section 1.8.a to one person.  The two incumbent OSMs are listed below and serve as the emergency contact for CGF when they are on rotation:

Central Gas Facility Emergency Contacts (Per Section 1.8.a):

Alternate Name	Title of Person/Position
Tim Johnson     CCP & CGF Onshore Site Manager
Jeff Michels	CCP & CGF Onshore Site Manager
